WaistLVLegRaiseCrunch.name: Lever Lying Leg Raise Crunch (plate loaded)
WaistLVLegRaiseCrunch.preparation: Lie supine on machine with lower legs between padded bars. Grasp handles on each side.
WaistLVLegRaiseCrunch.execution: Pull handles toward legs while pulling lower leg bar toward arms by flexing waist and hips. Return and repeat.

WaistLVLyingCrunchPL.name: Lever Lying Crunch (plate loaded)
WaistLVLyingCrunchPL.preparation: Lie on machine with feet on foot bar. Place forearms on bars at sides or grasp handles above to each side.
WaistLVLyingCrunchPL.execution: With hips stationary, raise upper back pad by flexing waist. Return and repeat.
WaistLVLyingCrunchPL.comments: Lever fulcrum should be aligned with waist, not hips. See Spot Reduction Myth.

WaistLVLyingLegHipRaise.name: Lever Lying Leg-Hip Raise (plate loaded)
WaistLVLyingLegHipRaise.preparation: Lie supine on machine with lower legs between padded bars. Grasp handles on each side.
WaistLVLyingLegHipRaise.execution: Pull lower leg bar up by flexing hips toward arms by flexing hips then waist. Continue to raise knees toward shoulders by flexing waist, raising hips from board. Return until waist and hips are extended down to original position. Repeat.
WaistLVLyingLegHipRaise.comments: Rectus Abdominis and Obliques dynamically contract only if actual waist flexion occurs. With no waist flexion, Rectus Abdominis and External Oblique will only isometrically contract to stabilize pelvis and waist during hip flexion. It may be necessary to completely flex hips before waist flexion is possible. See Spot Reduction Myth and Lower Ab Myth.
WaistLVLyingLegHipRaise.stabilizers: latissimusdorsi, deltoidposterior, teresmajor, tricepsbrachii, pectoralissternal, quadriceps
WaistLVLyingLegHipRaise.synergists: iliopsoas, sartorius, obliques, adductors, pectineus, tensorfasciaelatae, quadriceps

WaistLVSeatedLegRaiseCrunchPL.name: Lever Seated Leg Raise Crunch (plate loaded)
WaistLVSeatedLegRaiseCrunchPL.preparation: Sit on machine with back against back support and lower legs under padded bar. Grasp handles above to each side.
WaistLVSeatedLegRaiseCrunchPL.execution: Pull handles down while pulling lower leg bar up by flexing waist and pelvis. Return and repeat.
WaistLVSeatedLegRaiseCrunchPL.comments: Weight plates added to upper segment adds resistance, whereas weight plates added to lower segment decreases resistance. Seat can also be turned to either side to emphasize obliques. See Spot Reduction Myth.
WaistLVSeatedLegRaiseCrunchPL.stabilizers: latissimusdorsi, tricepsbrachii, tensorfasciaelatae, pectoralissternal, sartorius, deltoidposterior, teresmajor, pectineus, quadriceps

WaistLVVerticalLegHipRaise.name: Lever Vertical Leg-Hip Raise (plate loaded)
WaistLVVerticalLegHipRaise.preparation: Grasp handles slightly to front and stand on foot bar with knees slightly bent and hips against pad.
WaistLVVerticalLegHipRaise.execution: Raise legs as high as possible by flexing hips then waist. Return and repeat.
WaistLVVerticalLegHipRaise.comments: Exercise is typically performed without added resistance. Rectus Abdominis and Obliques only dynamically contract only if actual waist flexion occurs. With no waist flexion, Rectus Abdominis and External Oblique will only isometrically contract to stabilize pelvis and waist during hip flexion see Lever Vertical Leg Raise. Waist flexion will occur earlier in lift if legs are straighter or Hamstrings are not that flexible. See Spot Reduction Myth and Lower Ab Myth.
WaistLVVerticalLegHipRaise.synergists: iliopsoas, sartorius, adductors, pectineus, tensorfasciaelatae, quadriceps, obliques
